message_1: Find the Laurent series expansion of the function f(z) = 1/z at the point z = 2i.
message_2:
To find the Laurent series expansion of the function f(z) = 1/z at the point z = 2i, we first rewrite the function in terms of (z - 2i). We can do this by factoring out 1/(z - 2i + 2i) from the function:

f(z) = 1/z = 1/((z - 2i) + 2i)

Now, we can rewrite the function as:

f(z) = 1/((z - 2i) + 2i) = (1/2i) * 1/(1 - (-1/2i)(z - 2i))

Now we can use the geometric series formula to expand the function:

1/(1 - x) = 1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + ...

In our case, x = -1/2i(z - 2i). So the Laurent series expansion of f(z) at the point z = 2i is:

f(z) = (1/2i) * (1 - 1/2i(z - 2i) + (1/2i)^2(z - 2i)^2 - (1/2i)^3(z - 2i)^3 + ...)

f(z) = (1/2i) - 1/4(z - 2i) - 1/8i(z - 2i)^2 + 1/16(z - 2i)^3 + ...

This is the Laurent series expansion of the function f(z) = 1/z at the point z = 2i.
